um
to really get into that you'll start to
understand a lot about the internals of
the product because uh tap is what we
use inside of one cluster to keep
cluster members in sync with each other
so as you do a right to one node the
very first thing we do after that hits
our network adapter and our memory is
enqueue it to send to another node for
replica so that you're less likely to
lose data same the same kind of queuing
system will send it to disk as well and
latency is you know to go to disk are
going to be longer than going to a
remote node most of the time and that's
all via tab so tap is essentially a fire
hose of the activity on the cluster so
that it can keep all the nodes in sync
with each other and it's uh it's a
little smarter than that it only sends
each node the data that it needs to know
about as far as which shards it's in
charge of
so we are doing some work I would say
um this this may be coming out soon or
we're actually experimenting with a
couple different ways to do this but tap
is a natural way to get a real-time feed
of what's happening in the cluster so if
you wanted to keep something like an
elastic search index or some other index
system up to date with your changes in
the cluster one way you could do it is
with tap that's going to have very low
latencies but what we've found is that
if we do the indexing based on after
it's been written disk so rather than
sending it to the external indexer as
soon as it hits memory we wait for it to
drain through the disk queue and then
pull it back out off a disk you're more
likely to end up with a consistent you
know something that's more kind of
easier to deal with as a developer
because in in the most extreme case with
tap you could have something show up in
your search index before it shows up in
a replica for instance but with the disk
queue then you really know that your
index reflects what's stored so for that
we use the same type technology that
powers our across data center
replication which is based on the
couchdb replication which is essentially
its killer feature so for that you
essentially have you know if you've got
a 16 node cluster they're just going to
trickle those updates push them out to
whatever index interior you're using as
they hit disk
